user_request: Write a Shakespearean sonnet about death not being proud.
final_poem:
When Death, proud tyrant, lists to hear his praise,
Believing he has found a willing pen
To sing his epitaph before his season—
Forsooth! As though the grave could hold its case.
I'll not exalt thee, Death, although thou'rt seen
Outstrip all other ills that men sustain:
Thou art no lord o'er me. O, let thy train
Draw shorter, shrivel in thy death-bed's woof,
Before thy pomp have made thy kingdom real!
For what the living fear, the dead shall not:
No hourly visit, no eternal sleep,
Shall wake thee, nor shalt thou taste rest, except
The world's sweet wakings have been mistook for thine.
I am no psalmist. Yet I must refuse
The lie that gives thy title wings to fly.
